results.title: The School of Stanley J. Ellis
results.brief_description:
A short history of Stanley J. Ellis (b. 1899), influential artisan and teacher in the field of decorative metalwork and enamelling whose intricate work represents some of the finest examples of craftsmanship to be produced in the arts and craft movement of early 20th century Australia. His work is permanently held at the Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum in regional Victoria and in this film we see some of those highly acclaimed pieces. The film also features interviews with Peter Perry (Director, Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum) and Beth Sinclair, one of Ellis’s students.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and made in association with the Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum.

results.creator_credit: Jack Pearce, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Jack Pearce may have missed the war, there was still plenty of dangerous work for him to do, clearing mines up the Queensland coast for the Australian Navy.

results.title: Mourning & memory (a fabric memorial)
results.brief_description:
Short documentary about the Korean War Honour Roll Quilt made by the Coleraine Sit and Sew Group to commemorate the 340 Australian soldiers killed in the Korean War. Includes stills and personal commentary from the Coleraine community and some of those who contributed to the 1000 hours of work it took to complete the quilt.
Made by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Nola Gunning, Sherri Robertson, Maurie Butterworth, Lynn Gunning, Melba Plush and Janet Stanton.

results.title: Reproductive technology: facts and issues
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Pearl, Neil Barrett and Environment Audio Visuals
results.brief_description: This video is designed for students in years 10-12. Part one looks at recent technological advances in the field of reproduction and Part two raises some of the legal and ethical issues involved in such technology.

results.title: Reminiscing
results.creator_credit: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.

results.title: Report: Endeavour anchor
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Don Murray, Australia. Dept. of Transport and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The recovery and restoration of the anchor abandoned by explorer Captain James Cook on the Great Barrier Reef in 1770. Shows the search for the missing anchor by Australian scientists, and its discovery on the sea bed on Christmas Day, 1971.

results.title: The Long road to independence
results.creator_credit: Mohammed Abdur Rahman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Serving in the Australian army in East Timor, Mohammed Abdur Rahman and his fellow soldiers were attacked by the Indonesian army many times and involved in some highly publicized events. Over time, Rahman became quite connected to the nation and its people, performing humanitarian work and witnessing East Timor’s struggle towards independence.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mohammed Abdur Rahman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Serving in the Australian army in East Timor, Mohammed Abdur Rahman and his fellow soldiers were attacked by the Indonesian army many times and involved in some highly publicized events. results.title: Working
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Alasdair Clayre, Patrick Lui and Nigel Houghton
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program is Part Six of a twelve episode documentary, The Heart of the Dragon. The documentary records what is actually happening in China today and it captures on film the lives of peasants, factory workers, Party officials, artists, scientists, and even millionaires.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Montagnon, Alasdair Clayre, Patrick Lui and Nigel Houghton
